[[File:蔡英文官方元首肖像照.png|thumb|[[Tsai Ing-wen]], elected as [[president of Taiwan]] in 2016]]
{{Women in society sidebar}} The status of '''women in Taiwan''' has been based on and affected by the traditional [[patriarchal]] views and social structure within Taiwanese society, which put women in a subordinate position to men, although the legal status of Taiwanese women has improved in recent years, particularly during the past two decades when the family law underwent several amendments.
==Marriage and family law== [[File:台北祭奠復興航空235號班機空難罹難者_(4).jpg|thumb|Young women in Taiwan]] [[File:Chinese_Bhiksuni_Taiwan_Vesak_Festival.jpeg|thumb|Taiwanese [[bhiksuni]] (Buddhist nun) at a Vesak celebration, serving Oolong tea]] Throughout the 20th century, married women's rights were severely restricted, but they gradually improved, especially due to legal changes made in the last 20 years (the family law was revised five times between 1996 and 2002).<ref name="nccu.edu.tw">{{cite web|url=http://www3.nccu.edu.tw/~hschen/book_summary/2005-isbn8973006320.htm|title=Chen, Hwei-syin〈Changess in Marriage and Family-Related Laws in Taiwan: From Male Dominance to Gender Equality〉|author=|date=|website=www3.nccu.edu.tw|accessdate=22 April 2018}}</ref> In 1895, Taiwan came under Japanese rule and Japanese marriage laws (which discriminated against women) were applied.<ref name="nccu.edu.tw"/> After Japan's defeat in 1945, the section of family law from the Civil Law promulgated on the Republican mainland in 1930, came into force in Taiwan, too (family law was later changed in the mainland by the communist regime, but this did not apply to Taiwan).<ref name="nccu.edu.tw"/> The 1930 Taiwanese Civil Code provided limited rights to Taiwanese women, such as having no right in deciding their residence, the lack of right to own property, the lack of right to file a divorce, the lack of self-protection, and the lack of right to child custody, and discrimination against illegitimate children.<ref name=HF>[http://www.hartford-hwp.com/archives/55/002.html ''Taiwanese Women's Rights - Call for HELP''], ''From the Awakening Foundation in Taipei, Taiwan'', hartford-hwp.com, 15 March 1995</ref><ref name="nccu.edu.tw"/> The situation of married women improved slightly due to changes made in 1985 and 1996. By 1998, the new regulations had made divorce a little easier, allowed the wife to keep her own property registered in her name before 1985 without proving that she previously owned it; and allowed the judge to consider the [[Best interests|best interest of children]] when evaluating the custody of children in a divorce case.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://taiwan.yam.org.tw/womenweb/st/98e/e_law.htm|title=The Report on Women's Status in Taiwan, Legal Status|author=|year=1998|website=taiwan.yam.org.tw|accessdate=22 April 2018}}</ref> Yet these changes did not go as "far" as giving wives equal rights with husbands, as the continuation of the influence of patriarchal ideology with regards to family matters was maintained: the male still had superiority in decisions related to the wife's residence, disciplinary measures for their offsprings, and managing property.<ref name=Yam>[http://taiwan.yam.org.tw/womenweb/st/98e/e_law.htm ''The Report on Women's Status in Taiwan''], taiwan.yam.org.tw</ref> In 1998, the Domestic Violence Prevention Law<ref>http://www.hsph.harvard.edu/population/domesticviolence/CHINAtai.dv.98.htm</ref> came into force, dealing with [[domestic violence]].<ref name="nccu.edu.tw"/> New changes to the family law between 1998 and 2000, provided that the husband and wife's domicile is that which is agreed upon by them, rather than necessarily that of the husband's; and amended the law on legal guardians of a minor.<ref name="nccu.edu.tw1">{{cite web|url=http://www3.nccu.edu.tw/~hschen/book_summary/2005-isbn8973006320.htm#Marriage-Related+Law+in+Taiwan+in+the+Last+Two+Decades|title=Chen, Hwei-syin〈Changess in Marriage and Family-Related Laws in Taiwan: From Male Dominance to Gender Equality〉|author=|date=|website=www3.nccu.edu.tw|accessdate=22 April 2018}}</ref> Marriage regulations are currently based on [[gender equality]], being found in ''Chapter II- Marriage'' of the Civil Code (Articles 972 - 1058).<ref name="moj.gov.tw">http://law.moj.gov.tw/Eng/LawClass/LawAll.aspx?PCode=B0000001</ref> Mothers and fathers now have equal rights towards their children: the original Article 1089 stated that parental rights should be exercised by the father if the father and the mother did not share the same views, but this provision was declared unconstitutional (in contradiction of Article 7 of the Constitution),<ref>''The Legal Culture and System of Taiwan'', by Chang-fa Lo, pp 144</ref> and, as such, Article 1089 was amended to read: "[...] If there is inconsistency between the parents in the exercise of the rights in regard to the grave events of the minor child, they may apply to the court for the decision in accordance with the best interests of the child".<ref name="moj.gov.tw"/> Also, the Article 1019 (which stipulated that only the husband had the right to manage the shared property of a married couple, and had the right to use and receive profits from property that originally belonged to his wife, and not vice versa <ref name="nccu.edu.tw1"/>) was repealed.<ref name="moj.gov.tw"/>
==Constitutional protections== [[Women's rights]] are protected in the [[Constitution of Taiwan]]: Article 7 states: "''All citizens of the Republic of China, '''irrespective of sex''', religion, race, class, or party affiliation, shall be equal before the law''".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.president.gov.tw/Default.aspx?tabid=1107|title=Office of the President, ROC (Taiwan)|author=|date=|website=president.gov.tw|accessdate=22 April 2018}}</ref> The Additional Article 10, section 6 reads: ''The State shall protect the dignity of women, safeguard their personal safety, eliminate sexual discrimination, and further substantive gender equality.''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.president.gov.tw/Default.aspx?tabid=1037|title=Office of the President, ROC (Taiwan)|author=|date=|website=president.gov.tw|accessdate=22 April 2018}}</ref>
==Labour rights== Th Act of Gender Equality in Employment<ref>http://laws.mol.gov.tw/Eng/FLAW/FLAWDAT0201.asp</ref> ensures women's rights in the workforce. It was enacted in 2002 under the name of "Gender Equality in Employment Law of Taiwan", and later was amended and renamed the "Act of Gender Equality in Employment".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.bola.gov.taipei/Default.aspx?Create=1|title=勞動局英文網站|first=Taipei City Government|last=Department of Labor |date=28 December 2012|website=Department of Labor|accessdate=22 April 2018}}</ref>
==Sex-selective abortion== As in other parts of [[East Asia]], [[sex-selective abortion]] is reported to happen in Taiwan.<ref>http://www.econ.yale.edu/~nq3/NANCYS_Yale_Website/resources/papers/LiuLinQian_20130831.pdf</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.taipeitimes.com/News/front/archives/2011/12/08/2003520201|title=Taiwan’s gender balance worsening as more parents abort female fetuses - Taipei Times|author=|date=|website=www.taipeitimes.com|accessdate=22 April 2018}}</ref> <ref>{{cite journal|jstor=10.1086/682685|title=Abortion Legalization, Sex Selection, and Female University Enrollment in Taiwan|first=Priti|last=Kalsi|date=22 April 2018|publisher=|journal=Economic Development and Cultural Change|volume=64|issue=1|pages=163–185|accessdate=|doi=10.1086/682685}}</ref> The Department of Health has taken measures to curb this practice .<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.chinapost.com.tw/taiwan/national/national-news/2011/05/16/302521/DOH-to.htm|title=The China Post|author=|date=|website=The China Post|accessdate=22 April 2018}}</ref>
